page.title: 18NATURE, HAYDON BRIDGE.
page.content: West of Haydon Bridge the{Tyne}runs east between woodland & meadow, where in spring, Oyster-catcher, Sandpiper & Kingfisher nest along its banks. The deep pool at{Lipwood}offers food & shelter to migratory{salmon & sea {trout}which are{fished-for}by locals. The wood at{Whitechapel}is the home of the badger & roe deer. Woodpeckers, owls, warblers & finches nest here & heron in the pine wood close to the R. {Allen}which joins the Tyne at Whitechapel.Woodland gives way to heath & crag north of Whitechapel. There the kestrel lives, whilst among crag & rock the fox as her cubs on nearby{Barcombe.On Muckle Moss,}wild flowers grow, such as Bog Asphodel, Cross-leaved Heath, Sun-dew & Bog Cotton,along with Cranberries & Crowberries.
